thread.title: Have the Seattle Seahawks lost their identity? Former Seahawk Michael Robinson thinks so
thread.title_full: Have the Seattle Seahawks lost their identity? Former Seahawk Michael Robinson thinks so | The Seattle Times

author: Bob Condotta
title: Have the Seattle Seahawks lost their identity? Former Seahawk Michael Robinson thinks so
text:
In the wake of the Seattle Seahawks’ 2-4 start there are no shortage of opinions about what has gone wrong.
Greg Cosell of Yahoo.com broke down Carolina’s final drive on Sunday and wondered if the Seahawks are doing too much on defense, noting that a Seattle trademark the past few years has been its simplicity (though if you have heard Hugh Millen on KJR-AM this week, he has also noted that the Seahawks stayed largely in one defense on the previous 80-yard drive and likely switched things up on the last drive since that hadn’t worked).
Bucky Brooks of NFL.com, meanwhile, wrote in detail how he thinks teams have caught on to Seattle’s famed Cover 3 defense and that the Seahawks need to adapt to their perceived vulnerabilities.
What’s wrong with the Seahawks was also a hot topic on the NFL Network last night in a discussion featuring former Seahawks Michael Robinson and Nate Burleson.
Most Read Stories Seahawks’ Fred Jackson crashes car; Cops say no evidence of drag racing Fugitive felon, linked to motorcycle gang, captured in Lynnwood after 4-month hunt Oregon alum to abusive Huskies fans: This rivalry doesn't need you Loss of middle-income jobs seen as threat to region’s competitiveness Seattle Seahawks Monday injury report: Nine players sit out Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Robinson says he thinks the players are fine but that the team is going through “an identity crisis right now.”
Burleson, meanwhile, said he thinks it’s “time to panic” saying he thinks there is no clear identity on offense and that teams are no longer scared of Seattle’s secondary.
Here are some of those quotes, as provided by the NFL Network:
On what is wrong with the Seahawks defense: 
Michael Robinson: “I don’t think there is anything wrong with them. I really don’t. These guys, they’ve been through everything together, they’re battle-tested and if you look at last year they were in the same position last year through six games as they are right now. Actually, the defense is performing better this year at this point than they were last year. I think they’re just going through really an identity crisis as a team right now. They have to figure out each year who they are. It’s not the year before. It’s not like people are just scared of the Seahawks anymore; they’re not just going to go out on the field and beat teams. I look at the offensive side of the ball, they’re not finishing drives. They have one of the worst offensives in the fourth quarter and I think that’s the big problem.” 
Nate Burleson: “We had this conversation Week 1 and Week 2, and I said it’s time to panic. I talked to the people in Seattle and I said it was time to panic because there are things they need to fix that will start to rear its head later in the season. Right now we’re at the midway point almost and we’re seeing the same things. We’re seeing the lack of production offensively, no true identity; they fed Jimmy Graham a little bit more which was great. But now on the defensive side of the ball, what scared people most was that secondary. People aren’t scared of that secondary, in particular tight end play. You look at Tyler Eifert and what he did with the Cincinnati Bengals – they went right over the top of this ferocious secondary…Greg Olsen got in the endzone. If you’re looking at Kam [Chancellor], you’re looking at [Richard] Sherman, you’re looking at Earl Thomas, the guys that used to make those plays aren’t making those plays. You might shutdown a receiver or two, but they need to watch out for these tight ends for the rest of the season.” 
Robinson: “They’re not finishing this year. Maybe it’s getting to a point where Pete has been there awhile, the core group of guys have been there for a while…maybe the message is running a little thin. Maybe the guys are tired of hearing the same old things in every team meeting.” 
On the Seahawks’ motivation: 
Burleson: “I’m not going to speak on their individual motivation. I’m just saying as a team collectively it’s hard to get yourself up when you already won that championship…[Earl Thomas] also said there is some stuff that I want to talk about that I can’t say right now. You know what that tells me? There is trouble in the waters. You have guys bickering and pointing to each other, yelling in high definition – those are things we didn’t see the last couple of years.” 
On the Seahawks defense: 
Burleson: “We also have to talk about the linebackers and pressure on quarterbacks. There are quarterbacks sitting in the pocket more confident than ever against this team. That’s a lot different than what we’ve seen in the years past. Quarterbacks used to get rattled when they faced the Seahawks. They’re not so rattled anymore.” 
Bob Condotta : 206-515-5699 or bcondotta@seattletimes.com ; on Twitter: @bcondotta . Bob Condotta covers the Seahawks for the Seattle Times. He provides daily coverage of the team throughout the year.
